title: All Blacks captain Read, hooker Coles likely to miss France tests
text:
April 18, 2018 / 10:47 PM / Updated 13 hours ago All Blacks captain Read, hooker Coles likely to miss France tests Reuters Staff 3 Min Read 
WELLINGTON (Reuters) - All Blacks captain Kieran Read and first-choice hooker Dane Coles are unlikely to be selected for the three-test series against France in June as they recover from long-term injuries, coach Steve Hansen said on Thursday. FILE PHOTO: Rugby Union - New Zealand Captains Run - Surenois Rugby Club, Suresnes, France - November 10, 2017 New Zealand's Kieran Read during the captains run REUTERS/Benoit Tessier 
Read underwent back surgery following the All Blacks’ end of year tour to Europe after a protruding disc was causing leg pain while Coles ruptured knee ligaments. 
“I don’t think he’ll (Read) be back until after the French series but that’s not a fait accompli at this point,” Hansen told New Zealand’s Radio Sport. 
“We’ll just take our time and as I said about a month ago, he knows his body and we can’t afford to come back too early and damage it again and miss another six months and maybe even miss the World Cup. 
“We’ll just take it one day at a time and one week at a time.” 
Coles, who had issues with concussion last year that kept him out of the British and Irish Lions series, is having trouble with his rehabilitation following knee surgery. 
“Dane is having a few problems with his knee too - he can’t seem to straighten it,” Hansen said. 
“He’s gone back to the surgeon and the surgeon has put him back in a brace at night to try to help him get full extension. 
“Once that happens he’ll make progress pretty quickly. He is unlikely to be available for June.” 
Hansen’s likely replacement for Read is Otago Highlanders number eight Liam Squire, who became the first choice-blindside flanker last season. 
Squire, however, has suffered another broken thumb and is not due back until next month, while stalwart Jerome Kaino has been ruled out for six weeks with a hamstring injury. He is also moving to France at the end of the Super Rugby season. 
Highlanders number eight Luke Whitelock, who played against Wales last year, and Auckland Blues loose forward Akira Ioane are now likely to come into contention for the squad. 
Canterbury Crusaders hooker Codie Taylor is expected to take the starting berth against France for the three-test series starting in Auckland on June 9 before matches in Wellington and Dunedin. Reporting by Greg Stutchbury; Editing by Ed Osmond
